text.p: DynarchLIB is a small, portable and efficient JavaScript framework providing the following:

li.p: An unified coding style suitable for writing small and elegant code, which leads to naturally small and fast applications.
A collection of utility functions and useful extensions on top of standard JavaScript objects, which makes programming easier and more fun.
A rich and extensible set of widgets (user interface controls) having an uniform (but customizable) look and feel and a sane API.
A coherent event system — unifies DOM events with custom events and makes widgets behave as standard UI elements.
A server communication framework — provides an easy way to interoperate with a backend server via XML or JSON RPC requests.
Additionally, we provide 〈DlSocket〉, an object that you can use to create an arbitrary TCP/IP connection with the server. This functionality requires Flash Player (it's a small SWF file of about 1K).
Strong 〈DlCryptAES|cryptographic functions〉 which you can use to encrypt/decrypt data when for any reasons you can't use SSL.

text.p: DynarchLIB is self-contained. It is not based on Prototype, nor jQuery nor anything else. I started DynarchLIB before I even knew about these libraries. They are great tools, by the way, but DynarchLIB is just different in purpose; it represents a higher level, where you don't usually deal with DOM elements and DOM events, but with widgets having a custom event system instead; internally, DynarchLIB does the dirty work for you.

DynarchLIB is designed with standards in mind. In an ideal world, it will work on any browser. (Well, in fact, in an ideal world, there would only be one browser and it would be open-source). But since we don't live in an ideal world, here's the current status: most things work in all modern browsers, that is, Firefox, IE7, Safari, Konqueror and Opera (most things also work with IE6, but I definitely can't call it a modern browser).

Even though DynarchLIB has been reasonably tested with all major browsers, you should remember that there's no silver bullet. If you want to make sure that your application will support a particular browser, you do have to test.

Though they are very different browsers, they are both very capable for rich AJAX applications. Our main development platform is Firefox, but we extensively test what we do with IE7 too. DynarchLIB should work as documented in both Firefox and IE7.

This documentation might look weird in Internet Explorer 6, due to its lack of PNG support. It's been more than 10 years since PNG has been standardised, therefore I decided to use it for the presentation pages.

We are also using PNG images in order to draw dialog round corners and shadows. Code based on DynarchLIB will still work in IE6, but won't look as good as in a modern browser (it automatically won't display round corners and shadows).
These problems do not apply to IE7, which—eleven years after PNG has became a standard—finally introduces proper PNG support.

If you are using Firefox to test these samples and you have Firebug installed, we recommend you to disable it. Otherwise certain operations might seem slow. We don't know the reason for this but we suspect it's because Firebug must hook on a lot of browser events in order to provide all its great features; this in turn makes our scripts run slower.

Firebug is a great debugger and profiler—a great tool for development—but when you want to test your application in real-world conditions always disable Firebug (preferably use a browser profile with no extensions).

This application is an interactive documentation to DynarchLIB. It contains simple to advanced samples of how to use the toolkit efficiently. You can run most of these samples directly through this application, and you can also edit them and test your changes.
